While some claims in the dossier have been disputed or unverified, it is inaccurate to say it was entirely fabricated. Regarding the 'fine people' hoax, the claim that Trump called neo-Nazis 'fine people' is a mischaracterization. In his speech, Trump did say there were 'very fine people on both sides' but also stated that he was not referring to neo-Nazis or white nationalists, whom he condemned.
misinformation_details.correction: The Steele dossier was funded by the Clinton campaign and the DNC, but it was compiled by Christopher Steele, and not all of its claims have been proven false. Trump did say there were 'very fine people on both sides' during the Charlottesville incident, but he also explicitly condemned neo-Nazis and white nationalists in the same speech.

In the United States, the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act of 1986 does provide certain legal protections to vaccine manufacturers, but it does not grant them blanket immunity for all side effects or for fraudulent behavior such as hiding negative data. Manufacturers can still be held liable for willful misconduct. Additionally, the Vaccine Injury Compensation Program (VICP) allows individuals to seek compensation for vaccine-related injuries.
misinformation_details.correction: Vaccine manufacturers have certain legal protections under the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act, but they are not immune from liability for willful misconduct or fraud. The Vaccine Injury Compensation Program allows individuals to seek compensation for vaccine-related injuries.
